15.87.text: I essentially drag sledges for a living,

17.62.text: so it doesn't take an awful lot to flummox me intellectually,

20.80.text: but I'm going to read this question

22.35.text: from an interview earlier this year:

24.81.text: "Philosophically, does the constant supply of information

30.94.text: or replace our dreams of achieving?

33.76.text: After all, if it is being done somewhere by someone,

38.84.text: then why bother leaving the house?"

42.35.text: I'm usually introduced as a polar explorer.

44.99.text: I'm not sure that's the most progressive or 21st-century

47.30.text: of job titles, but I've spent more than two percent now

52.06.text: of my entire life living in a tent inside the Arctic Circle,

55.79.text: so I get out of the house a fair bit.

59.32.text: And in my nature, I guess, I am a doer of things

62.86.text: more than I am a spectator or a contemplator of things,

67.36.text: and it's that dichotomy, the gulf between ideas and action

71.58.text: that I'm going to try and explore briefly.

74.45.text: The pithiest answer to the question "why?"

77.78.text: that's been dogging me for the last 12 years

80.15.text: was credited certainly to this chap, the rakish-looking gentleman

82.93.text: standing at the back, second from the left,

85.19.text: George Lee Mallory. Many of you will know his name.

87.82.text: In 1924 he was last seen disappearing into the clouds

91.81.text: near the summit of Mt. Everest.

93.49.text: He may or may not have been the first person to climb Everest,

96.74.text: more than 30 years before Edmund Hillary.

98.72.text: No one knows if he got to the top. It's still a mystery.

101.41.text: But he was credited with coining the phrase, "Because it's there."

104.48.text: Now I'm not actually sure that he did say that.

107.17.text: There's very little evidence to suggest it, but what he did say

111.98.text: and again, I've printed this. I'm going to read it out.

115.03.text: "The first question which you will ask

116.99.text: and which I must try to answer is this:

119.48.text: What is the use of climbing Mt. Everest?

123.26.text: And my answer must at once be, it is no use.

125.95.text: There is not the slightest prospect of any gain whatsoever.

129.71.text: Oh, we may learn a little about the behavior

131.58.text: of the human body at high altitudes,

133.66.text: and possibly medical men may turn our observation

136.33.text: to some account for the purposes of aviation,

139.36.text: but otherwise nothing will come of it.

141.56.text: We shall not bring back a single bit of gold or silver,

143.94.text: and not a gem, nor any coal or iron.

146.54.text: We shall not find a single foot of earth that can be planted

149.34.text: with crops to raise food. So it is no use.

153.48.text: If you cannot understand that there is something in man

155.14.text: which responds to the challenge of this mountain

157.81.text: and goes out to meet it, that the struggle

161.04.text: is the struggle of life itself upward and forever upward,

165.49.text: then you won't see why we go.

168.74.text: What we get from this adventure is just sheer joy,

171.87.text: and joy, after all, is the end of life.

174.80.text: We don't live to eat and make money.

177.01.text: We eat and make money to be able to enjoy life.

179.47.text: That is what life means, and that is what life is for."

184.38.text: Mallory's argument that leaving the house,

187.83.text: embarking on these grand adventures is joyful and fun,

190.27.text: however, doesn't tally that neatly with my own experience.

194.18.text: The furthest I've ever got away from my front door

197.58.text: was in the spring of 2004. I still don't know exactly

200.72.text: what came over me, but my plan was to make

203.23.text: a solo and unsupported crossing of the Arctic Ocean.

207.47.text: I planned essentially to walk from the north coast of Russia

210.03.text: to the North Pole, and then to carry on to the north coast of Canada.

213.36.text: No one had ever done this. I was 26 at the time.

216.27.text: A lot of experts were saying it was impossible,

218.52.text: and my mum certainly wasn't very keen on the idea.

224.23.text: The journey from a small weather station on the north coast

227.16.text: of Siberia up to my final starting point,

229.34.text: the edge of the pack ice, the coast of the Arctic Ocean,

231.89.text: took about five hours, and if anyone watched fearless

235.35.text: Felix Baumgartner going up, rather than just coming down,

238.67.text: you'll appreciate the sense of apprehension,

241.27.text: as I sat in a helicopter thundering north,

244.58.text: and the sense, I think if anything, of impending doom.

247.24.text: I sat there wondering what on Earth I had gotten myself into.

250.93.text: There was a bit of fun, a bit of joy.

252.97.text: I was 26. I remember sitting there

254.81.text: looking down at my sledge. I had my skis ready to go,

257.41.text: I had a satellite phone, a pump-action shotgun

259.65.text: in case I was attacked by a polar bear.

261.67.text: I remember looking out of the window and seeing the second helicopter.

263.96.text: We were both thundering through this incredible Siberian dawn,

267.45.text: and part of me felt a bit like a cross between Jason Bourne

270.31.text: and Wilfred Thesiger. Part of me

273.20.text: felt quite proud of myself, but mostly I was just utterly terrified.

279.53.text: And that journey lasted 10 weeks, 72 days.

281.62.text: I didn't see anyone else. We took this photo next to the helicopter.

284.12.text: Beyond that, I didn't see anyone for 10 weeks.

286.67.text: The North Pole is slap bang in the middle of the sea,

288.62.text: so I'm traveling over the frozen surface of the Arctic Ocean.

291.88.text: NASA described conditions that year as the worst since records began.

295.99.text: I was dragging 180 kilos of food and fuel and supplies,

299.64.text: about 400 pounds. The average temperature for the 10 weeks

302.24.text: was minus 35. Minus 50 was the coldest.

304.94.text: So again, there wasn't an awful lot of joy or fun to be had.

312.21.text: One of the magical things about this journey, however,

313.75.text: is that because I'm walking over the sea,

315.85.text: over this floating, drifting, shifting crust of ice

319.91.text: that's floating on top of the Arctic Ocean is

322.11.text: it's an environment that's in a constant state of flux.

324.06.text: The ice is always moving, breaking up, drifting around,

326.40.text: refreezing, so the scenery that I saw for nearly 3 months

329.86.text: was unique to me. No one else will ever, could ever,

333.31.text: possibly see the views, the vistas, that I saw for 10 weeks.

338.34.text: And that, I guess, is probably the finest argument for leaving the house.

342.30.text: I can try to tell you what it was like,

346.18.text: but you'll never know what it was like,

348.03.text: and the more I try to explain that I felt lonely,

350.96.text: I was the only human being in 5.4 million square-miles,

354.67.text: it was cold, nearly minus 75 with windchill on a bad day,

358.98.text: the more words fall short, and I'm unable to do it justice.

362.81.text: And it seems to me, therefore, that the doing,

367.00.text: you know, to try to experience, to engage, to endeavor,

372.30.text: rather than to watch and to wonder, that's where

377.69.text: the real meat of life is to be found,

379.91.text: the juice that we can suck out of our hours and days.

383.86.text: And I would add a cautionary note here, however.

386.34.text: In my experience, there is something addictive

388.43.text: about tasting life at the very edge of what's humanly possible.

392.87.text: Now I don't just mean in the field of

397.39.text: but also in the fields of pancreatic cancer,

399.58.text: there is something addictive about this, and in my case,

401.49.text: I think polar expeditions are perhaps not that far removed

405.42.text: I can't explain quite how good it is until you've tried it,

409.13.text: but it has the capacity to burn up all the money I can get my hands on,

412.94.text: to ruin every relationship I've ever had,

416.52.text: so be careful what you wish for.

420.92.text: Mallory postulated that there is something in man

423.30.text: that responds to the challenge of the mountain,

425.94.text: and I wonder if that's the case whether there's something

427.97.text: in the challenge itself, in the endeavor, and particularly

431.03.text: in the big, unfinished, chunky challenges that face humanity

434.14.text: that call out to us, and in my experience that's certainly the case.

440.23.text: that's been calling out to me for most of my adult life.

443.51.text: Many of you will know the story.

444.93.text: This is a photo of Captain Scott and his team.

447.52.text: Scott set out just over a hundred years ago to try

449.40.text: to become the first person to reach the South Pole.

452.66.text: No one knew what was there. It was utterly unmapped

454.49.text: at the time. We knew more about the surface of the moon

456.51.text: than we did about the heart of Antarctica.

459.26.text: Scott, as many of you will know, was beaten to it

462.18.text: by Roald Amundsen and his Norwegian team,

464.47.text: who used dogs and dogsleds. Scott's team were on foot,

466.82.text: all five of them wearing harnesses and dragging around sledges,

469.25.text: and they arrived at the pole to find the Norwegian flag already there,

473.68.text: I'd imagine pretty bitter and demoralized.

476.94.text: All five of them turned and started walking back to the coast

479.21.text: and all five died on that return journey.

482.79.text: There is a sort of misconception nowadays that

485.03.text: it's all been done in the fields of exploration and adventure.

488.65.text: When I talk about Antarctica, people often say,

491.23.text: hasn't that Blue Peter presenter just done it on a bike?"

494.42.text: Or, "That's nice. You know, my grandmother's going

498.01.text: on a cruise to Antarctica next year. You know.

500.64.text: Is there a chance you'll see her there?"

508.54.text: No one has ever walked from the very coast of Antarctica

510.87.text: to the South Pole and back again.

512.67.text: It is, arguably, the most audacious endeavor

515.44.text: of that Edwardian golden age of exploration,

518.06.text: and it seemed to me high time, given everything

520.62.text: we have figured out in the century since

522.54.text: from scurvy to solar panels, that it was high time

526.12.text: someone had a go at finishing the job.

527.90.text: So that's precisely what I'm setting out to do.

530.59.text: This time next year, in October, I'm leading a team of three.

533.16.text: It will take us about four months to make this return journey.

536.02.text: That's the scale. The red line is obviously halfway to the pole.

539.07.text: We have to turn around and come back again.

540.47.text: I'm well aware of the irony of telling you that we will be

542.71.text: blogging and tweeting. You'll be able to live

545.45.text: vicariously and virtually through this journey

547.88.text: in a way that no one has ever before.

550.89.text: And it'll also be a four-month chance for me to finally

553.47.text: come up with a pithy answer to the question, "Why?"

557.35.text: And our lives today are safer and more comfortable

562.28.text: than they have ever been. There certainly isn't much call

564.86.text: for explorers nowadays. My career advisor at school

568.72.text: never mentioned it as an option.

571.36.text: If I wanted to know, for example,

573.78.text: how many stars were in the Milky Way,

576.08.text: how old those giant heads on Easter Island were,

578.66.text: most of you could find that out right now

583.61.text: And yet, if I've learned anything in nearly 12 years now

586.37.text: of dragging heavy things around cold places,

589.46.text: it is that true, real inspiration and growth

593.42.text: only comes from adversity and from challenge,

597.68.text: from stepping away from what's comfortable and familiar

600.69.text: and stepping out into the unknown.

603.18.text: In life, we all have tempests to ride and poles to walk to,

606.72.text: and I think metaphorically speaking, at least,

608.53.text: we could all benefit from getting outside the house

611.40.text: a little more often, if only we could summon up the courage.

615.28.text: I certainly would implore you to open the door just a little bit

618.50.text: and take a look at what's outside.
